1â†’# My Jarvis Desktop Architecture
     2â†’
     3â†’## Repository
     4â†’- **GitHub URL**: https://github.com/erezgit/my-jarvis-desktop
     5â†’- **Project Type**: AI-Powered Desktop Application with Claude Code WebUI Integration
     6â†’- **Framework**: Electron + React 19 + TypeScript + Claude Code SDK
     7â†’- **Current Version**: 1.10.0
     8â†’- **Status**: âœ… Production-Ready AI Chat Application with Workspace Management
     9â†’
    10â†’## Git & SSH Configuration
    11â†’
    12â†’### SSH Key Setup (Required for Committing & Pushing)
    13â†’
    14â†’**SSH Key Location**: `/workspace/.ssh/`
    15â†’- Private key: `/workspace/.ssh/id_ed25519`
    16â†’- Public key: `/workspace/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub`
    17â†’- SSH config: `/workspace/.ssh/config`
    18â†’
    19â†’**Key Fingerprint**: `SHA256:zSMN1dRfGRVc8J6exCYGvXFXeo9jNqs0SxzwHxbOeH4`
    20â†’
    21â†’#### SSH Configuration File
    22â†’
    23â†’The SSH config at `/workspace/.ssh/config` is set up to use the custom SSH key location:
    24â†’
    25â†’```
    26â†’Host github.com
    27â†’    HostName github.com
    28â†’    User git
    29â†’    IdentityFile /workspace/.ssh/id_ed25519
    30â†’    IdentitiesOnly yes
    31â†’    StrictHostKeyChecking accept-new
    32â†’```
    33â†’
    34â†’#### Git Configuration
    35â†’
    36â†’The repository is configured to use SSH with a custom config file path:
    37â†’
    38â†’```bash
    39â†’# Remote URL (SSH)
    40â†’git remote -v
    41â†’# origin  git@github.com:erezgit/my-jarvis-desktop.git (fetch)
    42â†’# origin  git@github.com:erezgit/my-jarvis-desktop.git (push)
    43â†’
    44â†’# SSH command configuration
    45â†’git config core.sshCommand "ssh -F /workspace/.ssh/config"
    46â†’```
    47â†’
    48â†’**Why custom SSH config path is needed**: SSH normally looks in `/root/.ssh/` by default, but our keys are in `/workspace/.ssh/`. The git config setting tells git to use our custom location.
    49â†’
    50â†’### Testing SSH Connection
    51â†’
    52â†’Before committing/pushing, verify SSH connection to GitHub:
    53â†’
    54â†’```bash
    55â†’# Test connection (should show success message)
    56â†’ssh -F /workspace/.ssh/config -T git@github.com
    57â†’
    58â†’# Expected output:
    59â†’# Hi erezgit! You've successfully authenticated, but GitHub does not provide shell access.
    60â†’```
    61â†’
    62â†’### Complete Commit & Push Workflow
    63â†’
    64â†’#### Step 1: Check Repository Status
    65â†’
    66â†’```bash
    67â†’cd /workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop
    68â†’
    69â†’# Check current status
    70â†’git status
    71â†’
    72â†’# See recent commits
    73â†’git log --oneline -5
    74â†’
    75â†’# Check remote tracking
    76â†’git log --oneline --graph --all --decorate -10
    77â†’```
    78â†’
    79â†’#### Step 2: Stage Changes
    80â†’
    81â†’```bash
    82â†’# Stage specific files
    83â†’git add path/to/file1.tsx path/to/file2.ts
    84â†’
    85â†’# Or stage all changes
    86â†’git add .
    87â†’
    88â†’# Review staged changes
    89â†’git diff --cached
    90â†’```
    91â†’
    92â†’#### Step 3: Commit Changes
    93â†’
    94â†’```bash
    95â†’# Commit with message
    96â†’git commit -m "feat: Add new feature description
    97â†’
    98â†’Detailed explanation of changes if needed.
    99â†’
   100â†’ğŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)
   101â†’
   102â†’Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"
   103â†’```
   104â†’
   105â†’**Commit Message Format**:
   106â†’- First line: Type + brief description (e.g., `feat:`, `fix:`, `chore:`)
   107â†’- Blank line
   108â†’- Detailed explanation (optional)
   109â†’- Blank line
   110â†’- Claude Code attribution (standard)
   111â†’
   112â†’#### Step 4: Handle Diverged Branches (If Needed)
   113â†’
   114â†’If your branch and origin have diverged:
   115â†’
   116â†’```bash
   117â†’# Check divergence
   118â†’git status
   119â†’# Output: "Your branch and 'origin/main' have diverged..."
   120â†’
   121â†’# Option 1: Pull with rebase (creates linear history)
   122â†’git pull --rebase origin main
   123â†’
   124â†’# Option 2: Pull with merge (creates merge commit)
   125â†’git pull origin main
   126â†’```
   127â†’
   128â†’**Rebase vs Merge**:
   129â†’- **Rebase**: Puts your commits on top of remote commits (cleaner history)
   130â†’- **Merge**: Creates a merge commit (preserves parallel development)
   131â†’
   132â†’**When to use rebase**:
   133â†’- Your commits haven't been pushed yet
   134â†’- You want a clean linear history
   135â†’- No conflicts expected
   136â†’
   137â†’#### Step 5: Push to GitHub
   138â†’
   139â†’```bash
   140â†’# Push to remote
   141â†’git push origin main
   142â†’
   143â†’# Expected output:
   144â†’# To github.com:erezgit/my-jarvis-desktop.git
   145â†’#    abc1234..def5678  main -> main
   146â†’```
   147â†’
   148â†’### Common Git Operations
   149â†’
   150â†’#### Amending Last Commit
   151â†’
   152â†’```bash
   153â†’# Add forgotten changes to last commit
   154â†’git add forgotten-file.ts
   155â†’git commit --amend --no-edit
   156â†’
   157â†’# Or amend commit message
   158â†’git commit --amend -m "Updated commit message"
   159â†’```
   160â†’
   161â†’**âš ï¸ Warning**: Only amend commits that haven't been pushed yet!
   162â†’
   163â†’#### Stashing Changes
   164â†’
   165â†’```bash
   166â†’# Save current changes temporarily
   167â†’git stash
   168â†’
   169â†’# List stashed changes
   170â†’git stash list
   171â†’
   172â†’# Apply most recent stash
   173â†’git stash pop
   174â†’
   175â†’# Apply specific stash
   176â†’git stash apply stash@{0}
   177â†’```
   178â†’
   179â†’#### Viewing History
   180â†’
   181â†’```bash
   182â†’# Graphical log
   183â†’git log --oneline --graph --all --decorate
   184â†’
   185â†’# Show file changes in commit
   186â†’git show --stat <commit-hash>
   187â†’
   188â†’# Show full diff for commit
   189â†’git show <commit-hash>
   190â†’```
   191â†’
   192â†’#### Undoing Changes
   193â†’
   194â†’```bash
   195â†’# Discard uncommitted changes to file
   196â†’git restore path/to/file.ts
   197â†’
   198â†’# Unstage file (keep changes)
   199â†’git restore --staged path/to/file.ts
   200â†’
   201â†’# Discard all uncommitted changes
   202â†’git restore .
   203â†’```
   204â†’
   205â†’### Troubleshooting
   206â†’
   207â†’#### SSH Connection Fails
   208â†’
   209â†’**Problem**: `Permission denied (publickey)`
   210â†’
   211â†’**Solution**:
   212â†’1. Verify SSH key is added to GitHub account
   213â†’2. Check key fingerprint matches:
   214â†’   ```bash
   215â†’   ssh-keygen -lf /workspace/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
   216â†’   # Should show: SHA256:zSMN1dRfGRVc8J6exCYGvXFXeo9jNqs0SxzwHxbOeH4
   217â†’   ```
   218â†’3. Test with verbose output:
   219â†’   ```bash
   220â†’   ssh -F /workspace/.ssh/config -vvv -T git@github.com
   221â†’   ```
   222â†’
   223â†’#### Can't Push - "Updates were rejected"
   224â†’
   225â†’**Problem**: Remote has commits you don't have
   226â†’
   227â†’**Solution**:
   228â†’```bash
   229â†’# Pull latest changes first
   230â†’git pull --rebase origin main
   231â†’
   232â†’# Then push
   233â†’git push origin main
   234â†’```
   235â†’
   236â†’#### Merge Conflicts During Pull
   237â†’
   238â†’**Problem**: Conflicting changes in same files
   239â†’
   240â†’**Solution**:
   241â†’1. Git will mark conflict files
   242â†’2. Edit files to resolve conflicts (look for `<<<<<<<`, `=======`, `>>>>>>>`)
   243â†’3. Stage resolved files:
   244â†’   ```bash
   245â†’   git add resolved-file.ts
   246â†’   ```
   247â†’4. Continue rebase:
   248â†’   ```bash
   249â†’   git rebase --continue
   250â†’   ```
   251â†’5. Push changes:
   252â†’   ```bash
   253â†’   git push origin main
   254â†’   ```
   255â†’
   256â†’### Best Practices
   257â†’
   258â†’1. **Pull before starting work**: Always `git pull` to get latest changes
   259â†’2. **Commit often**: Make small, focused commits
   260â†’3. **Test before committing**: Verify code works before committing
   261â†’4. **Write clear commit messages**: Describe what and why, not how
   262â†’5. **Review before pushing**: Use `git log` and `git diff` to review
   263â†’6. **Keep commits atomic**: One logical change per commit
   264â†’7. **Don't commit node_modules**: They're in .gitignore
   265â†’8. **Branch for experiments**: Use feature branches for major changes
   266â†’
   267â†’## Overview
   268â†’My Jarvis Desktop is a production-ready AI-powered Electron desktop application featuring a sophisticated **three-panel IDE-like interface** with integrated Claude AI capabilities. The application combines a file tree browser, file preview system, and Claude chat interface in a responsive, resizable layout. Built on the claude-code-webui foundation with extensive customizations, it provides comprehensive AI assistance with voice message support, environment isolation, and cross-platform deployment capabilities.
   269â†’
   270â†’## Current Stage: Production AI Chat Application
   271â†’
   272â†’### âœ… Architecture Foundation (Ticket #020)
   273â†’**Complete rewrite based on claude-code-webui integration**
   274â†’1. **claude-code-webui Integration**
   275â†’   - Built on proven claude-code-webui frontend architecture
   276â†’   - Modern React 19 + TypeScript + TailwindCSS stack
   277â†’   - Comprehensive message type system (chat, tool, plan, todo, thinking)
   278â†’   - UnifiedMessageProcessor for consistent message handling
   279â†’   - Professional UI with shadcn/ui components
   280â†’
   281â†’2. **Electron Desktop Wrapper**
   282â†’   - Clean Electron app wrapping the claude-code-webui
   283â†’   - electron-vite build system for optimized bundling
   284â†’   - Production-ready packaging with electron-builder
   285â†’   - Cross-platform compatibility (macOS, Windows, Linux)
   286â†’   - Native menu integration and window management
   287â†’
   288â†’3. **In-Process Server Architecture**
   289â†’   - claude-webui-server backend on port 8081 (embedded in main process)
   290â†’   - Direct runtime.serve() integration with NodeRuntime (jlongster pattern)
   291â†’   - Hono framework for high-performance HTTP server
   292â†’   - Environment-based Claude CLI authentication with PATH enhancement
   293â†’   - Automatic server lifecycle management within Electron main process
   294â†’
   295â†’4. **Claude Code SDK Integration** (Ticket #017)
   296â†’   - @anthropic-ai/claude-code ^1.0.108 integration
   297â†’   - Real-time streaming chat with NDJSON responses
   298â†’   - Comprehensive tool use support and error handling
   299â†’   - Session management and conversation history
   300â†’   - Abort controllers for request cancellation
   301â†’
   302â†’5. **Voice Message System** (Ticket #018-019, #022, #039, Environment Isolation)
   303â†’   - **Environment Isolation**: Complete separation of Jarvis environments resolved contamination
   304â†’   - **Backend-Frontend Architecture**: Backend generates voice files silently, frontend-only playback
   305â†’   - **TTS Integration**: External my-jarvis environment with isolated jarvis_voice.sh script
   306â†’   - **Electron File Access**: webSecurity: false configuration enables direct file:// protocol URLs
   307â†’   - **Audio Playback**: Native HTML5 Audio API with manual play/pause controls and transcript display
   308â†’   - **No Auto-Play**: User-controlled playback only (Ticket #039)
   309â†’   - **UnifiedMessageProcessor Integration**: Automatic VoiceMessage creation from Bash tool results
   310â†’
   311â†’6. **Three-Panel IDE Layout Architecture** (Tickets #055-056, Completed 2025-10-12)
   312â†’   - **Unified Chat Architecture**: Single ChatPage instance shared between desktop and mobile layouts (eliminates duplication)
   313â†’   - **Responsive Layout System**: Desktop (3-panel) and Mobile (single-panel) layouts with automatic switching
   314â†’   - **File Tree Panel**: VirtualizedFileTree with directory browsing (20% default width)
   315â†’   - **File Preview Panel**: Rich Markdown/MDX preview with syntax highlighting (50% default width)
   316â†’   - **Chat Panel**: ChatPage with Claude AI integration (30% default width)
   317â†’   - **Resizable Panels**: react-resizable-panels for user-customizable desktop layout
   318â†’   - **Mobile Layout Architecture**:
   319â†’     - **Dynamic Viewport Height**: Uses `h-dvh` (not `h-screen`) for proper mobile browser bar handling
   320â†’     - **Flex-Based Scrolling**: Flex container hierarchy enables internal message scrolling
   321â†’     - **iOS Safari Compatibility**: Viewport meta `maximum-scale=1` + 16px input font-size prevents auto-zoom
   322â†’     - **No Parent Height Constraints**: Removed `html, body, #root { height: 100%; }` to avoid viewport unit conflicts
   323â†’     - **Panel Container**: `flex-1 relative overflow-hidden` (no `min-h-0` which broke all panels)
   324â†’     - **Sticky Navigation**: Top bar with `sticky top-0 z-10` stays fixed during scrolling
   325â†’     - **Panel Wrappers**: Each panel (`h-full flex flex-col`) with proper flex context for children
   326â†’   - **ChatHeader Component**: Reusable header with view/panel switchers for both desktop and mobile
   327â†’   - **Mode System**: Jarvis mode (clean, minimal) vs Developer mode (technical details)
   328â†’
   329â†’7. **Token Usage Tracking** (Ticket #029)
   330â†’   - **Real-Time Visualization**: TokenContextBar with gradient color system
   331â†’   - **Context Awareness**: 200K context window tracking with percentage display
   332â†’   - **Architecture Pattern**: Context â†’ Hook â†’ Component (TokenUsageContext â†’ useTokenUsage â†’ TokenContextBar)
   333â†’   - **Integration**: UnifiedMessageProcessor extracts tokens from SDK result messages
   334â†’   - **Cumulative Tracking**: Session-based token accumulation across conversation
   335â†’
   336â†’8. **Rich Markdown/MDX File Preview** (Ticket #037, #041)
   337â†’   - **Markdown Rendering**: react-markdown with GitHub Flavored Markdown (remark-gfm)
   338â†’   - **MDX Support**: next-mdx-remote for interactive React components
   339â†’   - **Syntax Highlighting**: rehype-highlight for code blocks
   340â†’   - **Custom Interactive Components**:
   341â†’     - **AgentStatus**: Agent status display with visual indicators
   342â†’     - **MetricCard**: Metric visualization cards
   343â†’     - **TaskProgress**: Task tracking with progress bars
   344â†’     - **ArchitectureDiagram**: Architecture visualizations
   345â†’     - **TicketStack**: Visual ticket planning with collapsible cards, progress tracking, and status indicators (Ticket #041)
   346â†’   - **Theme Integration**: Dark/light mode support for all preview content
   347â†’
   348â†’9. **UI/UX Design System** (Ticket #040, v1.9.0-1.10.0 Polish)
   349â†’   - **Neutral Color Palette**: Consistent neutral-50/100/200/600/700 throughout
   350â†’   - **User Messages**: Green-100 background (HSL 140.6, 84.2%, 92.5%) with no label, timestamp below, sans-serif font
   351â†’   - **Typography**: Removed font-mono from chat messages, using system sans-serif for better readability
   352â†’   - **Transparent Messages**: Thinking, file operations, loading use transparent backgrounds
   353â†’   - **Static Input Field**: No focus ring, no shadow, neutral borders, outline-none
   354â†’   - **Simplified UI**: Removed "thinking -" prefix, "Initializing Jarvis" messages
   355â†’   - **Send Button**: Neutral-600/700 (minimal visual emphasis)
   356â†’   - **Page Background**: neutral-50 for lighter, cleaner appearance
   357â†’
   358â†’10. **Workspace Management System** (Tickets #042-043, #053-054)
   359â†’   - **SettingsContext Integration**: workingDirectory as persistent user preference
   360â†’   - **Multi-Workspace Support**: Switch between My Jarvis and My Jarvis Onboarding environments
   361â†’   - **Reactive File Tree**: Automatic reload when workspace changes
   362â†’   - **Persistent Selection**: Workspace choice saved to localStorage
   363â†’   - **Clean Architecture**: Single source of truth in SettingsContext, no prop drilling
   364â†’   - **Initialization Voice Fix** (Ticket #054): Removed duplicate voice announcements on startup
   365â†’   - **Directory Alignment** (Ticket #053): Consistent workspace path handling across desktop/cloud
   366â†’
   367â†’11. **Deployment Architecture**
   368â†’   - **Desktop**: Electron app with embedded claude-webui-server
   369â†’   - **Cloud Option**: claude-code-webui can be deployed as web application
   370â†’   - **My Jarvis Cloud**: Existing Docker-based cloud deployment
   371â†’   - **Unified Codebase**: Same frontend works across all platforms
   372â†’
   373â†’## Tech Stack
   374â†’
   375â†’### Frontend (Claude Code WebUI Foundation)
   376â†’- **React 19**: Latest React with concurrent features and improved performance
   377â†’- **TypeScript**: Complete type safety with strict configuration
   378â†’- **@anthropic-ai/claude-code ^1.0.108**: Official Claude Code SDK integration
   379â†’- **TailwindCSS**: Utility-first CSS framework for rapid UI development
   380â†’- **react-resizable-panels**: Resizable panel layout system for three-panel IDE interface
   381â†’- **@heroicons/react**: Modern SVG icon library for UI components
   382â†’- **Custom UI Components**: Purpose-built components for desktop application interface
   383â†’- **Streaming Architecture**: Real-time message processing with NDJSON
   384â†’- **Message Type System**: Comprehensive message types with type-safe processing:
   385â†’  - ChatMessage: User/assistant conversations (v1.10.0: green-100 background, no user label, sans-serif font)
   386â†’  - ToolMessage: Tool execution display
   387â†’  - ToolResultMessage: Tool result with structured data
   388â†’  - PlanMessage: Plan approval workflows
   389â†’  - ThinkingMessage: Claude's reasoning process (v1.10.0: no "thinking -" prefix)
   390â†’  - TodoMessage: Task management integration
   391â†’  - VoiceMessage: Audio playback with transcripts (v1.10.0: no auto-play, manual controls)
   392â†’- **UnifiedMessageProcessor**: Central message transformation pipeline
   393â†’  - Tool caching system for result correlation
   394â†’  - Message type detection and transformation logic
   395â†’  - Token extraction from SDK result messages (Ticket #029)
   396â†’  - Extensible pattern for custom message types
   397â†’  - Streaming and batch processing consistency
   398â†’- **Token Usage System**: Real-time context tracking (Ticket #029)
   399â†’  - TokenUsageContext with cumulative state management
   400â†’  - TokenContextBar with gradient color visualization (blue â†’ violet â†’ amber â†’ red)
   401â†’  - 200K context window tracking with percentage display
   402â†’- **File Preview System**: Rich document rendering (Tickets #037, #041)
   403â†’  - MarkdownRenderer for static .md files
   404â†’  - MDXRenderer for interactive .mdx components
   405â†’  - Syntax highlighting with rehype-highlight
   406â†’  - Custom MDX components (AgentStatus, MetricCard, TaskProgress, ArchitectureDiagram, TicketStack)
   407â†’
   408â†’### Backend (Electron + In-Process Server)
   409â†’- **Electron 37.3.1**: Cross-platform desktop framework with security best practices
   410â†’- **TypeScript**: Type-safe backend code with strict configuration
   411â†’- **In-Process Server**: claude-webui-server runs in Electron main process via runtime.serve()
   412â†’- **claude-webui-server**: Embedded backend server (jlongster pattern)
   413â†’  - **NodeRuntime**: Cross-platform HTTP server runtime
   414â†’  - **Hono Framework**: Modern web framework with middleware support
   415â†’  - **Port 8081**: Server port with CORS support, runs on 127.0.0.1
   416â†’- **IPC Communication**: Secure preload script for frontend-backend communication
   417â†’- **Authentication**: Environment-based Claude CLI authentication with PATH enhancement
   418â†’- **Logging**: Console-based logging with debug mode support

   426â†’## Architecture Decisions
   427â†’
   428â†’### Key Architectural Insights (Learned from Implementation)
   429â†’
   430â†’#### **Message Processing as Transformation Pipeline**
   431â†’The UnifiedMessageProcessor represents a sophisticated message transformation pipeline that serves as the bridge between Claude's SDK output and the UI layer:
   432â†’
   433â†’1. **Single Source of Truth**: All messages flow through one processor, ensuring consistency
   434â†’2. **Tool Correlation**: Tool caching enables intelligent result processing based on original tool context
   435â†’3. **Type Safety**: Strong TypeScript typing throughout the transformation process
   436â†’4. **Extensibility**: New message types can be added by extending the transformation logic
   437â†’
   438â†’#### **Tool Result Transformation Pattern**
   439â†’The voice message implementation revealed a powerful pattern for extending functionality:
   440â†’
   441â†’```typescript
   442â†’// Pattern: Detect tool type â†’ Parse results â†’ Create custom message
   443â†’if (toolName === "Bash" && command?.includes('jarvis_voice.sh')) {
   444â†’  // Parse tool output using regex patterns
   445â†’  const audioPath = parseAudioPath(content);
   446â†’  const transcript = parseTranscript(cachedCommand);
   447â†’
   448â†’  // Transform into custom message type
   449â†’  return createVoiceMessage(transcript, audioPath);
   450â†’}
   451â†’```
   452â†’
   453â†’This pattern enables:
   454â†’- **No Custom Tools Required**: Leverage existing Claude tools (Bash) for new functionality
   455â†’- **Seamless Integration**: Tool results automatically become rich UI components
   456â†’- **Maintainable Extensions**: Clear separation between detection, parsing, and creation logic
   457â†’
   458â†’#### **Streaming vs Batch Processing Unification**
   459â†’The processor handles both real-time streaming and historical data with identical logic:
   460â†’- **Streaming Mode**: Messages processed as they arrive from Claude SDK
   461â†’- **Batch Mode**: Historical messages processed for conversation loading
   462â†’- **Consistent Output**: Same transformation logic ensures identical UI rendering
   463â†’
   464â†’### claude-code-webui Foundation
   465â†’Our application is built on the proven claude-code-webui architecture, providing:
   466â†’- **Proven Codebase**: Battle-tested chat interface with comprehensive message handling
   467â†’- **Cross-Platform Deployment**: Same frontend works in Electron, web, and cloud environments
   468â†’- **Extensible Message System**: Support for multiple message types with consistent processing
   469â†’- **Professional UI**: Modern React components with shadcn/ui and TailwindCSS
   470â†’
   471â†’### Workspace Management Architecture (Tickets #042-043)
   472â†’
   473â†’The application implements a clean workspace management system through SettingsContext, enabling users to switch between different working directories while maintaining UI state consistency.
   474â†’
   475â†’**Architecture Pattern**:
   476â†’1. **SettingsContext as Single Source of Truth**
   477â†’   - `workingDirectory` added to SettingsContext alongside theme and enterBehavior
   478â†’   - Persisted to localStorage automatically with other settings
   479â†’   - Accessible via `useSettings()` hook throughout the application
   480â†’   - No prop drilling or local state duplication
   481â†’
   482â†’2. **Reactive File Tree Updates**
   483â†’   - VirtualizedFileTree receives `workingDirectory` as prop from DesktopLayout
   484â†’   - `useEffect` dependency on `workingDirectory` triggers automatic reload
   485â†’   - Parent directory structure refreshes when workspace changes
   486â†’   - Clean separation: DesktopLayout reads from context, FileTree reacts to props
   487â†’
   488â†’3. **Workspace Registry**
   489â†’   - Defined workspace list in GeneralSettings component
   490â†’   - Each workspace: `{ id, displayName, path }`
   491â†’   - Currently supports: My Jarvis and My Jarvis Onboarding
   492â†’   - Easily extensible for additional workspaces
   493â†’
   494â†’4. **Switching Flow**
   495â†’   ```
   496â†’   User clicks workspace â†’ GeneralSettings calls setWorkingDirectory()
   497â†’   â†’ SettingsContext updates and persists â†’ ChatPage reads new workingDirectory
   498â†’   â†’ DesktopLayout passes to VirtualizedFileTree â†’ File tree reloads
   499â†’   ```
   500â†’
   501â†’**Key Benefits**:
   502â†’- Clean architectural separation (settings vs conversation state)
   503â†’- Automatic persistence across app restarts
   504â†’- Reactive updates without manual refresh logic
   505â†’- Consistent pattern for adding workspace-related features
   506â†’
   507â†’### Mobile Layout Architecture (Tickets #055-056, October 2025)
   508â†’
   509â†’The unified mobile layout architecture eliminates code duplication and provides a production-ready mobile experience through careful viewport management and iOS Safari compatibility.
   510â†’
   511â†’**Unified Chat Pattern**:
   512â†’1. **Single ChatPage Instance**
   513â†’   - One ChatPage component shared between DesktopLayout and MobileLayout
   514â†’   - Created once in ResponsiveLayout with useMemo
   515â†’   - Passed as `chatInterface` prop to both layouts
   516â†’   - No conditional rendering or mobile-specific logic in ChatPage
   517â†’   - Eliminates duplicate code and ensures consistency
   518â†’
   519â†’2. **Responsive Layout Switching**
   520â†’   ```tsx
   521â†’   ResponsiveLayout (React fragment wrapper)
   522â†’   â”œâ”€â”€ DesktopLayout (lg+)
   523â†’   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ ChatPage in flex-1 panel
   524â†’   â””â”€â”€ MobileLayout (<lg)
   525â†’       â””â”€â”€ ChatPage in h-full panel wrapper
   526â†’   ```
   527â†’
   528â†’**Mobile Viewport Architecture**:
   529â†’1. **Dynamic Viewport Height (`h-dvh`)**
   530â†’   - Uses `h-dvh` (dynamic viewport height) NOT `h-screen` (100vh)
   531â†’   - Automatically recalculates when mobile browser UI shows/hides
   532â†’   - Prevents ~150px overflow caused by static 100vh calculations
   533â†’   - Critical for proper mobile browser bar handling
   534â†’
   535â†’2. **Parent Constraint Removal**
   536â†’   - Removed `html, body, #root { height: 100%; }` from global.css
   537â†’   - Parent height constraints conflict with h-dvh/h-screen calculations
   538â†’   - Clean viewport calculation from actual browser dimensions
   539â†’   - Matches my-jarvis-frontend reference architecture
   540â†’
   541â†’3. **Container Hierarchy**
   542â†’   ```tsx
   543â†’   MobileLayout (h-dvh flex flex-col)
   544â†’   â”œâ”€â”€ Nav Bar (sticky top-0 z-10)
   545â†’   â””â”€â”€ Panel Container (flex-1 relative overflow-hidden)
   546â†’       â””â”€â”€ Transition Wrapper (h-full)
   547â†’           â””â”€â”€ Panel Wrapper (h-full flex flex-col)
   548â†’               â””â”€â”€ ChatPage (h-full)
   549â†’                   â”œâ”€â”€ TokenBar (fixed height)
   550â†’                   â”œâ”€â”€ ChatMessages (flex-1 overflow-y-scroll)
   551â†’                   â””â”€â”€ ChatInput (fixed height)
   552â†’   ```
   553â†’
   554â†’4. **Flex-Based Scrolling**
   555â†’   - `flex-1` on panel container fills remaining space after nav
   556â†’   - `overflow-hidden` prevents page-level scrolling
   557â†’   - `h-full flex flex-col` on panel wrapper establishes flex context
   558â†’   - `flex-1 overflow-y-scroll` on ChatMessages enables internal scrolling
   559â†’
   560â†’**iOS Safari Compatibility**:
   561â†’1. **Auto-Zoom Prevention**
   562â†’   - Viewport meta: `maximum-scale=1.0, user-scalable=no`
   563â†’   - Input font-size: `text-base` (16px) not `text-sm` (14px)
   564â†’   - iOS Safari auto-zooms when input < 16px, breaking layout
   565â†’
   566â†’2. **Keyboard Handling**
   567â†’   - h-dvh automatically adjusts for keyboard appearance
   568â†’   - No manual vh calculations or resize listeners needed
   569â†’   - ChatInput stays fixed at bottom when keyboard shows
   570â†’
   571â†’**Anti-Patterns Avoided**:
   572â†’- âŒ Double height wrappers (ResponsiveLayout + MobileLayout both with h-screen)
   573â†’- âŒ min-h-0 on panel container (breaks all panels, not just chat)
   574â†’- âŒ Removing h-full from ChatPage before fixing parent constraints
   575â†’- âŒ Using h-screen (static) instead of h-dvh (dynamic)
   576â†’- âŒ Parent height constraints (html/body/root with height:100%)
   577â†’
   578â†’**Testing Results**:
   579â†’- âœ… No auto-zoom on input focus (iOS Safari)
   580â†’- âœ… Messages scroll internally, page doesn't scroll
   581â†’- âœ… Entry field always visible, even with many messages
   582â†’- âœ… Proper viewport height with/without browser bars
   583â†’- âœ… Works across all three panels (files, preview, chat)
   584â†’
   585â†’### Environment Isolation Architecture (Critical Solution)
   586â†’
   587â†’The application implements complete environment isolation to resolve Claude Code SDK contamination:
   588â†’
   589â†’**Problem Solved**: Claude Code SDK uses hierarchical CLAUDE.md discovery, causing environment contamination when multiple Jarvis environments exist in nested directories.
   590â†’
   591â†’**Solution Architecture**:
   592â†’1. **Complete Path Separation**
   593â†’   - Main Jarvis: `/Users/erezfern/Workspace/jarvis/` (development environment)
   594â†’   - My Jarvis: `/Users/erezfern/Workspace/my-jarvis/` (isolated production environment)
   595â†’   - No nested directories or shared paths between environments
   596â†’
   597â†’2. **Independent Voice Systems**
   598â†’   - Each environment has its own jarvis_voice.sh script with different configurations
   599â†’   - Main Jarvis: Full voice capabilities for development
   600â†’   - My Jarvis: Backend-silent mode (AUTO_PLAY="false" permanently set)
   601â†’
   602â†’3. **Workspace Management Integration**
   603â†’   - Desktop app uses SettingsContext for workspace selection (Tickets #042-043)
   604â†’   - All file operations constrained to selected workspace
   605â†’   - Prevents cross-contamination during development vs production use
   606â†’
   607â†’4. **Claude Code SDK Isolation**
   608â†’   - Each environment discovers its own CLAUDE.md configuration
   609â†’   - No inheritance or hierarchical discovery conflicts
   610â†’   - Complete independence between development and production contexts
   611â†’
   612â†’### In-Process Server Architecture (jlongster Pattern)
   613â†’The Electron integration uses an in-process server pattern (inspired by jlongster/actual-server) with environment isolation:
   614â†’
   615â†’1. **Main Process** (Electron)
   616â†’   - Embeds claude-webui-server directly using runtime.serve() - no child process fork
   617â†’   - NodeRuntime provides cross-platform HTTP server runtime
   618â†’   - Server lifecycle managed within Electron main process (startup in app.whenReady, cleanup in before-quit)
   619â†’   - PATH enhancement for CLI tool discovery in GUI environments (macOS apps don't inherit terminal PATH)
   620â†’   - Provides secure IPC communication via preload script
   621â†’
   622â†’2. **Backend Server** (claude-webui-server)
   623â†’   - In-process server running on port 8081 within main Electron process (127.0.0.1)
   624â†’   - Hono framework for high-performance HTTP server
   625â†’   - Claude Code SDK integration with streaming support
   626â†’   - CORS-enabled API endpoints for frontend communication
   627â†’   - Environment-based authentication inheritance
   628â†’   - Isolated my-jarvis environment for voice script execution
   629â†’
   630â†’3. **Frontend** (React Application)
   631â†’   - claude-code-webui React components and logic
   632â†’   - UnifiedMessageProcessor for consistent message handling
   633â†’   - Real-time streaming with NDJSON protocol
   634â†’   - Comprehensive message type system
   635â†’   - Local file access enabled (webSecurity: false) for voice message playback
   636â†’
   637â†’**Key Benefits of In-Process Pattern**:
   638â†’- No IPC overhead between processes
   639â†’- Simpler lifecycle management (single process to start/stop)
   640â†’- Direct memory access between server and Electron
   641â†’- Easier debugging (single process to attach to)
   642â†’- No port conflicts or process spawning issues
   643â†’
   644â†’### Multi-Platform Deployment Strategy
   645â†’The architecture supports multiple deployment options:
   646â†’
   647â†’1. **Desktop (Electron)**: Full-featured desktop application with embedded server
   648â†’2. **Web Application**: Direct deployment of claude-code-webui as standalone web app
   649â†’3. **Cloud Deployment**: Docker-based deployment (My Jarvis Cloud example)
   650â†’4. **Hybrid**: Mix of desktop and cloud based on user preferences
   651â†’
   652â†’### Authentication & Configuration
   653â†’
   654â†’1. **Environment-Based Authentication**
   655â†’   - Claude CLI authentication inherited from parent process
   656â†’   - No additional configuration required for authenticated environments
   657â†’   - Seamless authentication in packaged Electron builds
   658â†’   - Fallback error handling for unauthenticated environments
   659â†’
   660â†’2. **Configuration Management** (SettingsContext Architecture)
   661â†’   - Settings stored via localStorage in frontend
   662â†’   - Centralized SettingsContext for all user preferences:
   663â†’     - Theme (light/dark)
   664â†’     - Enter behavior (send/newline)
   665â†’     - Working directory (workspace selection)
   666â†’     - Message display mode (Jarvis/Developer)
   667â†’   - Automatic persistence on settings changes
   668â†’   - Type-safe settings with AppSettings interface
   669â†’
   670â†’3. **Error Handling**
   671â†’   - Graceful degradation when Claude CLI unavailable
   672â†’   - User-friendly error messages for authentication issues
   673â†’   - Connection status monitoring and recovery
   674â†’   - Request timeout and abort controller support
   675â†’
   676â†’### Message Processing Architecture (UnifiedMessageProcessor)
   677â†’The heart of the messaging system is the UnifiedMessageProcessor, which transforms raw Claude SDK messages into UI-ready message objects:
   678â†’
   679â†’1. **Message Transformation Pipeline**
   680â†’   - Processes streaming NDJSON messages from Claude Code SDK
   681â†’   - Handles both real-time streaming and batch history processing
   682â†’   - Converts Claude SDK message types into typed UI message objects
   683â†’   - Maintains consistent output regardless of data source (streaming vs history)
   684â†’
   685â†’2. **Tool Caching System**
   686â†’   - Caches tool_use information (tool name, parameters, unique ID) when tools are invoked
   687â†’   - Enables correlation between tool execution and tool results
   688â†’   - Critical for determining message transformations based on tool type
   689â†’   - Used for permission error handling and result processing
   690â†’
   691â†’3. **Message Type Detection & Transformation**
   692â†’   - Examines tool results and applies transformation logic
   693â†’   - Creates appropriate message objects (ChatMessage, ToolMessage, VoiceMessage, etc.)
   694â†’   - Handles special cases like voice script detection in Bash tool results
   695â†’   - Extensible pattern for adding new message types
   696â†’
   697â†’4. **Voice Message Implementation (Tickets #018-019, #022, #039)**
   698â†’   - **Detection Logic**: Identifies jarvis_voice.sh commands in Bash tool results
   699â†’   - **Result Parsing**: Extracts audio file paths and transcript text using regex patterns
   700â†’   - **Message Creation**: Transforms Bash results into VoiceMessage objects with file:// URLs
   701â†’   - **User-Controlled Playback**: Manual play/pause controls (v1.9.0: no auto-play)
   702â†’
   703â†’5. **Token Usage Tracking (Ticket #029)**
   704â†’   - **Result Message Processing**: Extracts usage.input_tokens + usage.output_tokens from SDK result messages
   705â†’   - **Cumulative Tracking**: Updates global TokenUsageContext with session total
   706â†’   - **Context Integration**: Calls context.onTokenUpdate() callback with new token data
   707â†’   - **Non-Intrusive**: Does not replace or hide result messages, adds side-effect callback only
   708â†’
   709â†’### Voice Message System (Complete Implementation with Environment Isolation)
   710â†’The voice integration demonstrates the power of the UnifiedMessageProcessor architecture with complete environment separation:
   711â†’
   712â†’1. **Environment Isolation Architecture**
   713â†’   - **Isolated my-jarvis Environment**: `/Users/erezfern/Workspace/my-jarvis/` separate from main Jarvis
   714â†’   - **Claude Code SDK Hierarchical Discovery**: Resolved contamination between environments
   715â†’   - **Independent Voice Scripts**: Each environment has its own jarvis_voice.sh configuration
   716â†’   - **Complete Path Separation**: No shared dependencies or cross-contamination
   717â†’
   718â†’2. **Voice Generation (Backend Silent Mode)**
   719â†’   - TTS via isolated jarvis_voice.sh script execution through Bash tool
   720â†’   - Backend script permanently set to AUTO_PLAY="false" (no backend audio)
   721â†’   - Audio files generated in `/Users/erezfern/Workspace/my-jarvis/tools/voice/` directory
   722â†’   - Unique filename generation with timestamp and content correlation
   723â†’
   724â†’3. **Message Processing Flow (UnifiedMessageProcessor)**
   725â†’   - Claude executes Bash tool with external jarvis_voice.sh command
   726â†’   - UnifiedMessageProcessor detects voice script in cached tool information
   727â†’   - Parses Bash output for audio file path using regex patterns
   728â†’   - Extracts transcript from cached command parameters
   729â†’   - Creates VoiceMessage with autoPlay: true instead of ToolResultMessage
   730â†’   - Enables seamless voice integration without custom Claude tools
   731â†’
   732â†’4. **Electron Integration (Local File Access)**
   733â†’   - **webSecurity: false** configuration in BrowserWindow for local file access
   734â†’   - Direct file:// protocol URLs for native Electron compatibility
   735â†’   - No HTTP server required for audio file serving
   736â†’   - Native HTML5 Audio API for playback controls
   737â†’   - Security trade-off: Local file access vs web security restrictions
   738â†’
   739â†’5. **Frontend Integration (User-Controlled Playback)** (v1.9.0 Update)
   740â†’   - VoiceMessage type in comprehensive message system
   741â†’   - Type guards ensure proper component rendering
   742â†’   - Voice UI components with play/pause controls and transcript display
   743â†’   - Manual user-controlled playback only (no auto-play)
   744â†’   - User controls: Play/pause/stop with visual feedback
   745â†’
   746â†’### Performance Optimization
   747â†’
   748â†’1. **React Optimization**
   749â†’   - React 19 concurrent features for improved rendering
   750â†’   - Efficient state management with minimal re-renders
   751â†’   - Proper key usage in dynamic lists and components
   752â†’   - Memory-efficient message handling for long conversations
   753â†’
   754â†’2. **Streaming Performance**
   755â†’   - NDJSON streaming for real-time message processing
   756â†’   - Chunked response handling without blocking UI
   757â†’   - Efficient message buffer management
   758â†’   - Request abort controllers for cancelled operations
   759â†’
   760â†’3. **Electron Optimization**
   761â†’   - Context isolation for security and performance
   762â†’   - Minimal main process operations
   763â†’   - Efficient IPC communication patterns
   764â†’   - Optimized bundling with electron-vite

   933â†’## Deployment Options
   934â†’
   935â†’### 1. Desktop Application (Current Implementation)
   936â†’```
   937â†’my-jarvis-desktop/                  # Electron app with embedded server

   941â†’```
   942â†’
   943â†’### 2. Fly.io Cloud Deployment (Production) âœ…
   944â†’
   945â†’**Successfully deployed at**: https://my-jarvis-desktop.fly.dev
   946â†’
   947â†’The application has been successfully deployed to Fly.io using a programmatic approach. This deployment provides cloud-based access to the My Jarvis Desktop application without requiring local installation.
   948â†’
   949â†’#### **Deployment Architecture**
   950â†’
   951â†’```
   952â†’Fly.io Machine (San Jose, sjc)
   953â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Machine ID: 78175e3c947468
   954â†’â”œâ”€â”€ IPv4: 169.155.59.92
   955â†’â”œâ”€â”€ IPv6: 2a09:8280:1::a6:49c:0
   956â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Internal Port: 10000
   957â†’â”œâ”€â”€ Memory: 512MB
   958â†’â”œâ”€â”€ CPU: 1 shared
   959â†’â””â”€â”€ Volume: 1GB workspace
   960â†’```
   961â†’
   962â†’#### **Successful Deployment Steps** (October 15, 2025)
   963â†’
   964â†’The deployment was accomplished using Python with Fly.io's GraphQL API via curl. Here's what worked:
   965â†’
   966â†’**1. Install flyctl (Optional for verification)**
   967â†’```bash
   968â†’curl -L https://fly.io/install.sh | sh
   969â†’# Installed to: /Users/erezfern/.fly/bin/flyctl
   970â†’```
   971â†’
   972â†’**2. Set Environment Variable**
   973â†’```bash
   974â†’export FLY_API_TOKEN="your-fly-api-token"
   975â†’```
   976â†’
   977â†’**3. Verify Token Works**
   978â†’```bash
   979â†’python3 -c "
   980â†’import json, urllib.request, ssl
   981â†’ctx = ssl.create_default_context()
   982â†’ctx.check_hostname = False
   983â†’ctx.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
   984â†’
   985â†’token = 'FlyV1 ...'
   986â†’req = urllib.request.Request(
   987â†’    'https://api.fly.io/graphql',
   988â†’    data=json.dumps({'query': '{viewer{id email}}'}).encode('utf-8'),
   989â†’    headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {token}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
   990â†’)
   991â†’with urllib.request.urlopen(req, context=ctx) as response:
   992â†’    print(json.dumps(json.loads(response.read()), indent=2))
   993â†’"
   994â†’```
   995â†’
   996â†’**4. Allocate Public IP Addresses** (Critical Step)
   997â†’
   998â†’The app was already deployed but wasn't accessible due to missing public IP addresses. Allocating both IPv4 and IPv6 resolved all DNS and accessibility issues:
   999â†’
  1000â†’```bash
  1001â†’# Allocate IPv4
  1002â†’python3 -c "
  1003â†’import json, urllib.request, ssl
  1004â†’ctx = ssl.create_default_context()
  1005â†’ctx.check_hostname = False
  1006â†’ctx.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
  1007â†’
  1008â†’data = {
  1009â†’    'query': 'mutation(\$input: AllocateIPAddressInput!) { allocateIpAddress(input: \$input) { ipAddress { id address type } } }',
  1010â†’    'variables': {'input': {'appId': 'my-jarvis-desktop', 'type': 'v4'}}
  1011â†’}
  1012â†’req = urllib.request.Request(
  1013â†’    'https://api.fly.io/graphql',
  1014â†’    data=json.dumps(data).encode('utf-8'),
  1015â†’    headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {token}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
  1016â†’)
  1017â†’with urllib.request.urlopen(req, context=ctx) as response:
  1018â†’    print(json.dumps(json.loads(response.read()), indent=2))
  1019â†’"
  1020â†’# Result: IPv4 169.155.59.92 allocated
  1021â†’
  1022â†’# Allocate IPv6
  1023â†’python3 -c "
  1024â†’import json, urllib.request, ssl
  1025â†’ctx = ssl.create_default_context()
  1026â†’ctx.check_hostname = False
  1027â†’ctx.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
  1028â†’
  1029â†’data = {
  1030â†’    'query': 'mutation(\$input: AllocateIPAddressInput!) { allocateIpAddress(input: \$input) { ipAddress { id address type } } }',
  1031â†’    'variables': {'input': {'appId': 'my-jarvis-desktop', 'type': 'v6'}}
  1032â†’}
  1033â†’req = urllib.request.Request(
  1034â†’    'https://api.fly.io/graphql',
  1035â†’    data=json.dumps(data).encode('utf-8'),
  1036â†’    headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {token}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
  1037â†’)
  1038â†’with urllib.request.urlopen(req, context=ctx) as response:
  1039â†’    print(json.dumps(json.loads(response.read()), indent=2))
  1040â†’"
  1041â†’# Result: IPv6 2a09:8280:1::a6:49c:0 allocated
  1042â†’```
  1043â†’
  1044â†’**5. Verify Deployment**
  1045â†’```bash
  1046â†’curl -I https://my-jarvis-desktop.fly.dev
  1047â†’# HTTP/2 200 âœ…
  1048â†’```

  1050â†’#### **Multi-User Deployment Strategy - Complete Guide**
  1051â†’
  1052â†’This section provides a **complete, step-by-step guide** for deploying separate My Jarvis Desktop instances for different users. Each user gets their own isolated Fly.io app with a unique subdomain (e.g., `my-jarvis-lilah.fly.dev`).
  1053â†’
  1054â†’**âœ… Verified Working** - This process was successfully tested on October 15, 2025 with Lilah's instance.
  1055â†’
  1056â†’---
  1057â†’
  1058â†’### **Prerequisites**
  1059â†’
  1060â†’1. **Fly.io API Token** - Get from dashboard or `flyctl auth token`
  1061â†’2. **Organization ID** - Find with GraphQL query (see below)
  1062â†’3. **Docker Image** - Existing deployed image from registry.fly.io
  1063â†’4. **Python 3** - For running deployment scripts
  1064â†’
  1065â†’---
  1066â†’
  1067â†’### **Step-by-Step Deployment Process**
  1068â†’
  1069â†’#### **Step 1: Get Your Organization ID**
  1070â†’
  1071â†’Before creating apps, you need your Fly.io organization ID:
  1072â†’
  1073â†’```python
  1074â†’import json, urllib.request, ssl
  1075â†’
  1076â†’ctx = ssl.create_default_context()
  1077â†’ctx.check_hostname = False
  1078â†’ctx.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
  1079â†’
  1080â†’token = 'FlyV1 ...'  # Your Fly.io API token
  1081â†’
  1082â†’org_query = {'query': '{ viewer { organizations { nodes { id name slug } } } }'}
  1083â†’
  1084â†’req = urllib.request.Request(
  1085â†’    'https://api.fly.io/graphql',
  1086â†’    data=json.dumps(org_query).encode('utf-8'),
  1087â†’    headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {token}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
  1088â†’)
  1089â†’
  1090â†’with urllib.request.urlopen(req, context=ctx) as response:
  1091â†’    result = json.loads(response.read())
  1092â†’    orgs = result['data']['viewer']['organizations']['nodes']
  1093â†’    print(f"Organization ID: {orgs[0]['id']}")
  1094â†’    # Example: zQpLKVXNGapwgH61jXMLyk5zbLcDez2YK
  1095â†’```
  1096â†’
  1097â†’#### **Step 2: Find the Docker Image Tag**
  1098â†’
  1099â†’Get the exact Docker image tag from your working instance:
  1100â†’
  1101â†’```python
  1102â†’query = {
  1103â†’    'query': '''
  1104â†’    {
  1105â†’      app(name: "my-jarvis-desktop") {
  1106â†’        machines {
  1107â†’          nodes {
  1108â†’            config {
  1109â†’              image
  1110â†’            }
  1111â†’          }
  1112â†’        }
  1113â†’      }
  1114â†’    }
  1115â†’    '''
  1116â†’}
  1117â†’
  1118â†’req = urllib.request.Request(
  1119â†’    'https://api.fly.io/graphql',
  1120â†’    data=json.dumps(query).encode('utf-8'),
  1121â†’    headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {token}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
  1122â†’)
  1123â†’
  1124â†’with urllib.request.urlopen(req, context=ctx) as response:
  1125â†’    result = json.loads(response.read())
  1126â†’    image = result['data']['app']['machines']['nodes'][0]['config']['image']
  1127â†’    print(f"Docker Image: {image}")
  1128â†’    # Example: my-jarvis-desktop:deployment-01K7JFWZY278ZS59P4J3SN0W91
  1129â†’```
  1130â†’
  1131â†’---
  1132â†’
  1133â†’### **Complete Deployment Script for New User**
  1134â†’
  1135â†’Here's the **complete, tested script** that creates a fully working user instance:
  1136â†’
  1137â†’```python
  1138â†’#!/usr/bin/env python3
  1139â†’"""
  1140â†’Deploy a new My Jarvis Desktop instance for a user on Fly.io
  1141â†’Usage: python3 deploy_user.py lilah FlyV1...
  1142â†’"""
  1143â†’
  1144â†’import json
  1145â†’import urllib.request
  1146â†’import ssl
  1147â†’import sys
  1148â†’import time
  1149â†’
  1150â†’def deploy_user_instance(username, fly_token, org_id, docker_image, region='sjc'):
  1151â†’    """
  1152â†’    Deploy a complete My Jarvis Desktop instance for a user
  1153â†’
  1154â†’    Args:
  1155â†’        username: User's name (becomes part of subdomain)
  1156â†’        fly_token: Fly.io API token
  1157â†’        org_id: Fly.io organization ID
  1158â†’        docker_image: Full Docker image path (e.g., registry.fly.io/my-jarvis-desktop:deployment-...)
  1159â†’        region: Fly.io region code (default: sjc = San Jose)
  1160â†’
  1161â†’    Returns:
  1162â†’        dict with deployment details
  1163â†’    """
  1164â†’
  1165â†’    ctx = ssl.create_default_context()
  1166â†’    ctx.check_hostname = False
  1167â†’    ctx.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE
  1168â†’
  1169â†’    app_name = f"my-jarvis-{username}"
  1170â†’
  1171â†’    print(f"ğŸš€ Deploying My Jarvis Desktop for {username}...")
  1172â†’    print(f"   App name: {app_name}")
  1173â†’    print(f"   Region: {region}")
  1174â†’    print()
  1175â†’
  1176â†’    # Step 1: Create Fly.io app
  1177â†’    print("Step 1/6: Creating Fly.io app...")
  1178â†’    create_app_data = {
  1179â†’        'query': 'mutation($input: CreateAppInput!) { createApp(input: $input) { app { id name } } }',
  1180â†’        'variables': {
  1181â†’            'input': {
  1182â†’                'name': app_name,
  1183â†’                'organizationId': org_id
  1184â†’            }
  1185â†’        }
  1186â†’    }
  1187â†’
  1188â†’    req = urllib.request.Request(
  1189â†’        'https://api.fly.io/graphql',
  1190â†’        data=json.dumps(create_app_data).encode('utf-8'),
  1191â†’        headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {fly_token}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
  1192â†’    )
  1193â†’
  1194â†’    with urllib.request.urlopen(req, context=ctx) as response:
  1195â†’        result = json.loads(response.read())
  1196â†’        if 'errors' in result:
  1197â†’            raise Exception(f"Failed to create app: {result['errors']}")
  1198â†’        print(f"   âœ… App created: {app_name}")
  1199â†’
  1200â†’    # Step 2: Create volume for workspace
  1201â†’    print("Step 2/6: Creating workspace volume...")
  1202â†’    volume_config = {
  1203â†’        'name': f'{username}_workspace',
  1204â†’        'size_gb': 1,
  1205â†’        'region': region
  1206â†’    }
  1207â†’
  1208â†’    req = urllib.request.Request(
  1209â†’        'https://api.machines.dev/v1/apps/{}/volumes'.format(app_name),
  1210â†’        data=json.dumps(volume_config).encode('utf-8'),
  1211â†’        headers={'Authorization': f'Bearer {fly_token}', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'},
  1212â†’        method='POST'
  1213â†’    )
  1214â†’
  1215â†’    with urllib.request.urlopen(req, context=ctx) as response:
  1216â†’        volume = json.loads(response.read())
  1217â†’        volume_id = volume['id']
  1218â†’        print(f"   âœ… Volume created: {volume_id}")
  1219â†’
  1220â†’    # Step 3: Create machine with COMPLETE configuration
  1221â†’    print("Step 3/6: Creating machine with complete configuration...")
  1222â†’
  1223â†’    # âš ï¸ CRITICAL: This configuration must match the working instance exactly
  1224â†’    machine_config = {

  1387â†’### **Critical Configuration Details** âš ï¸
  1388â†’
  1389â†’These settings are **ESSENTIAL** for the app to work. Missing any of these will cause failures:
  1390â†’
  1391â†’#### **1. Memory: 512MB (NOT 256MB)**
  1392â†’```python
  1393â†’'guest': {
  1394â†’    'memory_mb': 512  # âš ï¸ CRITICAL: 256MB is insufficient
  1395â†’}
  1396â†’```
  1397â†’**Why**: The application needs 512MB to run properly. With 256MB, the app starts but fails with HTTP 502/503 errors.
  1398â†’
  1399â†’#### **2. WebSocket Service for Terminal (Port 3001)**
  1400â†’```python
  1401â†’'services': [
  1402â†’    # HTTP/HTTPS service
  1403â†’    {...},
  1404â†’    # âš ï¸ CRITICAL: WebSocket service - DO NOT OMIT
  1405â†’    {
  1406â†’        'protocol': 'tcp',
  1407â†’        'internal_port': 3001,
  1408â†’        'ports': [{'port': 3001}]
  1409â†’    }
  1410â†’]
  1411â†’```
  1412â†’**Why**: Without this service, the terminal functionality won't work. This was the main issue with Lilah's first deployment.
  1413â†’
  1414â†’#### **3. Autostop and Autostart Configuration**
  1415â†’```python
  1416â†’'services': [{
  1417â†’    'autostop': 'suspend',
  1418â†’    'autostart': True,
  1419â†’    'min_machines_running': 0,
  1420â†’    'concurrency': {
  1421â†’        'type': 'connections',
  1422â†’        'hard_limit': 25,
  1423â†’        'soft_limit': 20
  1424â†’    }
  1425â†’}]
  1426â†’```
  1427â†’**Why**: Enables Fly.io's automatic scaling. Machines suspend when idle and auto-start on incoming requests.
  1428â†’
  1429â†’#### **4. Complete Environment Variables**
  1430â†’```python
  1431â†’'env': {
  1432â†’    'USER_ID': username,          # User identification
  1433â†’    'PORT': '10000',              # Internal HTTP port
  1434â†’    'NODE_ENV': 'production',     # Production mode
  1435â†’    'WORKSPACE_DIR': '/workspace', # Workspace mount path
  1436â†’    'PRIMARY_REGION': region,     # Region identifier
  1437â†’    'TERMINAL_WS_PORT': '3001'    # WebSocket port
  1438â†’}
  1439â†’```

  1443â†’### **Troubleshooting Common Issues**
  1444â†’
  1445â†’| Error | Cause | Solution |
  1446â†’|-------|-------|----------|
  1447â†’| HTTP 502 Bad Gateway | App not responding | Check memory (needs 512MB), verify services config |
  1448â†’| HTTP 503 Service Unavailable | Machine starting up | Wait 10-30 seconds for boot |
  1449â†’| DNS not resolving | Missing IP addresses | Ensure both IPv4 and IPv6 are allocated |
  1450â†’| Terminal not working | Missing port 3001 service | Add WebSocket service configuration |
  1451â†’| App crashes on startup | Insufficient memory | Increase memory_mb to 512 |

  1507â†’
  1508â†’### **Updating Existing Deployments** âš ï¸
  1509â†’
  1510â†’**CRITICAL**: When updating code for existing user instances, you MUST use the correct update procedure to avoid creating duplicate machines and volumes.
  1511â†’
  1512â†’#### **The Problem** (Learned October 16, 2025)
  1513â†’
  1514â†’When using `fly deploy` without flags, Fly.io:
  1515â†’1. âœ… Builds new Docker image successfully
  1516â†’2. âŒ Creates a **NEW machine** instead of updating existing one
  1517â†’3. âŒ Creates a **NEW volume** (1GB) leaving old volume orphaned
  1518â†’4. âŒ Results in **duplicate resources** and **increased costs**
  1519â†’
  1520â†’**Example**: Updating Lilah's instance created:
  1521â†’- 2 machines (old: `lilah-machine`, new: `long-paper-7608`)
  1522â†’- 2 volumes (old: `lilah_workspace`, new: `workspace_data`)
  1523â†’- Total storage showing as 2GB instead of 1GB
  1524â†’
  1525â†’#### **The Solution: Use `--update-only` Flag**
  1526â†’
  1527â†’To update existing deployments **without creating new resources**:
  1528â†’
  1529â†’```bash
  1530â†’# Navigate to project directory
  1531â†’cd /path/to/my-jarvis-desktop
  1532â†’
  1533â†’# Authenticate with Fly.io
  1534â†’fly auth login
  1535â†’
  1536â†’# Update existing machines ONLY (preserves volumes)
  1537â†’fly deploy --app my-jarvis-USERNAME --update-only
  1538â†’
  1539â†’# Alternative: Update specific machine by ID
  1540â†’fly machine update MACHINE_ID --app my-jarvis-USERNAME --image registry.fly.io/my-jarvis-USERNAME:deployment-XXXXX
  1541â†’```
  1542â†’
  1543â†’#### **Complete Update Procedure**
  1544â†’
  1545â†’**Step 1: Make Code Changes**
  1546â†’```bash
  1547â†’# 1. Update version number in package.json and SettingsModal.tsx
  1548â†’# 2. Commit changes to git
  1549â†’git add .
  1550â†’git commit -m "feat: Update to version X.Y.Z"
  1551â†’git push
  1552â†’```
  1553â†’
  1554â†’**Step 2: Deploy Update**
  1555â†’```bash
  1556â†’# Authenticate with Fly.io
  1557â†’fly auth login
  1558â†’
  1559â†’# Deploy update (builds new image and updates existing machines)
  1560â†’fly deploy --app my-jarvis-USERNAME --update-only
  1561â†’
  1562â†’# Monitor deployment
  1563â†’fly logs --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1564â†’```
  1565â†’
  1566â†’**Step 3: Verify Update**
  1567â†’```bash
  1568â†’# Check machine status
  1569â†’fly status --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1570â†’
  1571â†’# Verify only one machine exists
  1572â†’fly machines list --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1573â†’
  1574â†’# Verify only one volume exists
  1575â†’fly volumes list --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1576â†’
  1577â†’# Test deployment
  1578â†’curl -I https://my-jarvis-USERNAME.fly.dev
  1579â†’```
  1580â†’
  1581â†’#### **Cleanup After Incorrect Deployment**
  1582â†’
  1583â†’If you accidentally created duplicate machines/volumes:
  1584â†’
  1585â†’```bash
  1586â†’# 1. List all machines
  1587â†’fly machines list --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1588â†’
  1589â†’# 2. Stop old machine
  1590â†’fly machine stop OLD_MACHINE_ID --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1591â†’
  1592â†’# 3. Verify new machine is working
  1593â†’curl -I https://my-jarvis-USERNAME.fly.dev
  1594â†’
  1595â†’# 4. Destroy old machine (permanently)
  1596â†’fly machine destroy OLD_MACHINE_ID --app my-jarvis-USERNAME --force
  1597â†’
  1598â†’# 5. List volumes
  1599â†’fly volumes list --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1600â†’
  1601â†’# 6. Delete orphaned volume (if no important data)
  1602â†’fly volumes destroy OLD_VOLUME_ID --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1603â†’```
  1604â†’
  1605â†’#### **Key Flags Explained**
  1606â†’
  1607â†’| Flag | Purpose | When to Use |
  1608â†’|------|---------|-------------|
  1609â†’| `--update-only` | Update existing machines, don't create new ones | **Always use for updates** |
  1610â†’| `--detach` | Return immediately, don't wait for deployment | Background deployments |
  1611â†’| `--image` | Specify exact Docker image | When updating specific machine |
  1612â†’| `--force` | Skip confirmation prompts | Automated scripts |
  1613â†’
  1614â†’#### **Best Practices**
  1615â†’
  1616â†’1. **Always use `--update-only`** when deploying code changes to existing instances
  1617â†’2. **Monitor resources**: Check machines and volumes after each deployment
  1618â†’3. **Version tracking**: Update version number in code before deploying
  1619â†’4. **Test first**: Deploy to your own instance before updating user instances
  1620â†’5. **User data**: Volumes persist across updates, but back up important data
  1621â†’6. **Verify single resources**: Ensure only one machine and one volume per app
  1622â†’
  1623â†’#### **Troubleshooting Update Issues**
  1624â†’
  1625â†’| Issue | Cause | Solution |
  1626â†’|-------|-------|----------|
  1627â†’| Duplicate machines | Used `fly deploy` without `--update-only` | Stop and destroy old machine |
  1628â†’| Duplicate volumes | New machine created new volume | Destroy orphaned volume |
  1629â†’| Storage costs doubled | Two volumes allocated | Clean up old volume |
  1630â†’| App not responding | Multiple machines competing | Stop all but one machine |
  1631â†’| Data loss concern | Unsure which volume has data | Don't delete volumes, contact support |
  1632â†’
  1633â†’---
  1634â†’
  1635â†’### **Quick Deployment Method with fly deploy** âœ…
  1636â†’
  1637â†’**NEW**: This is the simpler method we successfully used for my-jarvis-erez and my-jarvis-erez-dev (October 16, 2025).
  1638â†’
  1639â†’This method is simpler than the Python script approach and uses Fly.io's CLI directly. The key difference is that it uses local files with `fly deploy`, which sends code to Fly's remote build service (Depot.dev) without requiring Docker on your machine or git push.
  1640â†’
  1641â†’#### **Prerequisites**
  1642â†’- Fly.io CLI installed: `curl -L https://fly.io/install.sh | sh`
  1643â†’- Authenticated: `fly auth login`
  1644â†’- Environment variable: `export FLY_API_TOKEN="your-token"`
  1645â†’
  1646â†’#### **Complete Deployment Steps**
  1647â†’
  1648â†’**Step 1: Create the Fly.io App**
  1649â†’```bash
  1650â†’# Create new app (replace USERNAME with actual username)
  1651â†’fly apps create my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1652â†’```
  1653â†’
  1654â†’**Step 2: Deploy Code**
  1655â†’```bash
  1656â†’# Navigate to project directory
  1657â†’cd /path/to/my-jarvis-desktop/projects/my-jarvis-desktop
  1658â†’
  1659â†’# Deploy code (uses local files, remote build service)
  1660â†’fly deploy --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1661â†’
  1662â†’# This will:
  1663â†’# - Package local files
  1664â†’# - Send to Depot.dev (Fly's remote builder)
  1665â†’# - Build Docker image in cloud
  1666â†’# - Deploy to your app
  1667â†’# - No local Docker or git push needed
  1668â†’```
  1669â†’
  1670â†’**Step 3: Allocate IP Addresses** âš ï¸ **CRITICAL - DON'T SKIP**
  1671â†’```bash
  1672â†’# Allocate IPv4 (required for DNS to work)
  1673â†’fly ips allocate-v4 --app my-jarvis-USERNAME -y
  1674â†’
  1675â†’# Allocate IPv6 (required for DNS to work)
  1676â†’fly ips allocate-v6 --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1677â†’```
  1678â†’
  1679â†’**Without these IP addresses, the app deploys but DNS won't resolve!**
  1680â†’
  1681â†’**Step 4: Verify Deployment**
  1682â†’```bash
  1683â†’# Check app status
  1684â†’fly status --app my-jarvis-USERNAME
  1685â†’
  1686â†’# Test accessibility
  1687â†’curl -I https://my-jarvis-USERNAME.fly.dev
  1688â†’# Should return: HTTP/2 200
  1689â†’```
  1690â†’
  1691â†’#### **Why This Method Works**
  1692â†’
  1693â†’1. **No Docker Required**: Fly uses remote build service (Depot.dev)
  1694â†’2. **No Git Push Required**: Uses local files directly
  1695â†’3. **Simple Commands**: Just create â†’ deploy â†’ allocate IPs
  1696â†’4. **Same Result**: Creates identical deployment to Python script method
  1697â†’
  1698â†’#### **Common Mistakes to Avoid**
  1699â†’
  1700â†’âŒ **Forgetting IP allocation** - App deploys but isn't accessible
  1701â†’âŒ **Using `fly deploy` for updates** - Creates duplicate machines (use `--update-only` instead)
  1702â†’âŒ **Skipping verification** - Always test with curl after deployment
  1703â†’
  1704â†’#### **When to Use This Method**
  1705â†’
  1706â†’- âœ… Creating new user instances (my-jarvis-USERNAME)
  1707â†’- âœ… First-time deployments
  1708â†’- âœ… Quick setup for development/staging environments
  1709â†’- âŒ NOT for updating existing deployments (use `--update-only` instead)
  1710â†’
  1711â†’---
  1712â†’
  1713â†’### **Example: Creating Lilah's Instance**
  1714â†’
  1715â†’This is the actual process that was successfully completed on October 15, 2025:

  1794â†’**Key Concepts for Multi-User Deployment:**
  1795â†’
  1796â†’1. **One App Per User**: Each user gets a separate Fly.io app with unique subdomain
  1797â†’2. **Shared Docker Image**: All apps can use the same Docker image from the registry
  1798â†’3. **Environment Variables**: Customize each instance with USER_ID or other env vars
  1799â†’4. **Resource Isolation**: Each app has its own machine, volume, and IP addresses
  1800â†’5. **Independent Scaling**: Each user instance can be scaled independently

  1869â†’### 3. My Jarvis Cloud (Alternative Web Deployment)

  1967â†’## Development Setup
  1968â†’
  1969â†’### Prerequisites
  1970â†’- Node.js 18+
  1971â†’- npm or pnpm
  1972â†’- Git
  1973â†’
  1974â†’### Commands
  1975â†’```bash
  1976â†’# Install dependencies
  1977â†’npm install
  1978â†’
  1979â†’# Run development server
  1980â†’npm run dev
  1981â†’
  1982â†’# Build for production
  1983â†’npm run build:mac   # macOS
  1984â†’npm run build:win   # Windows
  1985â†’npm run build:linux # Linux
  1986â†’
  1987â†’# Lint and format
  1988â†’npm run lint

  1991â†’
  1992â†’## Build Pipeline Architecture
  1993â†’
  1994â†’### Critical Build Process
  1995â†’
  1996â†’**IMPORTANT**: Production builds require TypeScript compilation. The backend cannot run without compiled JavaScript files.
  1997â†’
  1998â†’### Development vs Production Execution
  1999â†’
  2000â†’#### **Development Mode** (npm run dev)
  2001â†’```bash
  2002â†’# Development uses TypeScript directly
  2003â†’tsx cli/node.ts --port 8081 --host 127.0.0.1
  2004â†’```
  2005â†’- âœ… Uses `tsx` to run TypeScript files directly
  2006â†’- âœ… No compilation required
  2007â†’- âœ… Fast iteration and hot reload
  2008â†’- âœ… Works with source TypeScript files
  2009â†’
  2010â†’#### **Production Mode** (npm run build:mac)
  2011â†’```bash
  2012â†’# Production requires compiled JavaScript
  2013â†’node dist/cli/node.js --port 8081 --host 127.0.0.1
  2014â†’```
  2015â†’- âœ… Uses compiled JavaScript files from `dist/`
  2016â†’- âœ… No tsx dependency in packaged app
  2017â†’- âœ… Optimized for distribution
  2018â†’- âŒ **FAILS if dist/ directory missing**
  2019â†’
  2020â†’### Complete Build Pipeline
  2021â†’
  2022â†’#### **Step 1: prebuild** (Automatic)
  2023â†’```bash
  2024â†’"prebuild": "cd lib/claude-webui-server && npm install && npm run build"
  2025â†’```
  2026â†’1. Install backend dependencies
  2027â†’2. **Compile TypeScript â†’ JavaScript** (creates `dist/` directory)
  2028â†’3. **Critical**: This step MUST complete before Electron packaging
  2029â†’
  2030â†’#### **Step 2: Frontend Build**
  2031â†’```bash
  2032â†’"vite:build:app": "electron-vite build"
  2033â†’```
  2034â†’- Compiles React frontend
  2035â†’- Creates optimized bundles
  2036â†’
  2037â†’#### **Step 3: Electron Packaging**
  2038â†’```bash
  2039â†’"electron:build:mac": "electron-builder --mac"
  2040â†’```
  2041â†’- Packages both frontend and backend
  2042â†’- Creates installable .dmg file
  2043â†’
  2044â†’### Entry Point Detection (electron-node.cjs)
  2045â†’
  2046â†’The wrapper automatically detects environment and uses appropriate entry point:
  2047â†’
  2048â†’```javascript
  2049â†’// Auto-detection logic
  2050â†’const isProduction = process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' ||
  2051â†’                    !fs.existsSync(path.join(__dirname, 'node.ts'));
  2052â†’
  2053â†’const entryPoint = isProduction
  2054â†’  ? path.join(__dirname, '..', 'dist', 'cli', 'node.js')  // Compiled JS
  2055â†’  : path.join(__dirname, 'node.ts');                      // TypeScript
  2056â†’
  2057â†’// Uses appropriate runtime
  2058â†’const server = isProduction
  2059â†’  ? spawn('node', [entryPoint, '--port', port, '--host', '127.0.0.1'])
  2060â†’  : spawn('tsx', [entryPoint, '--port', port, '--host', '127.0.0.1']);
  2061â†’```
  2062â†’
  2063â†’### Build Dependencies
  2064â†’
  2065â†’#### **Required for Production**
  2066â†’- âœ… `lib/claude-webui-server/dist/cli/node.js` (compiled backend)
  2067â†’- âœ… `out/` directory (compiled frontend)
  2068â†’- âœ… All node_modules installed
  2069â†’
  2070â†’#### **Build Failure Symptoms**
  2071â†’- âŒ "ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED" in production builds
  2072â†’- âœ… Development works normally
  2073â†’- âŒ Missing `dist/` directory
  2074â†’- âŒ Backend server fails to start silently
  2075â†’
  2076â†’### Troubleshooting Build Issues
  2077â†’
  2078â†’#### **Problem**: Production build fails with connection errors
  2079â†’**Solution**:
  2080â†’1. Verify backend compilation: `cd lib/claude-webui-server && npm run build`
  2081â†’2. Check for `dist/cli/node.js` file existence
  2082â†’3. Rebuild completely: `npm run build:mac`
  2083â†’
  2084â†’#### **Problem**: "Development works, production fails"
  2085â†’**Root Cause**: Missing TypeScript compilation step
  2086â†’**Prevention**: Never remove `dist/` files without updating build pipeline
  2087â†’
  2088â†’#### **Problem**: Backend server startup timeout
  2089â†’**Diagnosis**: Check electron-node.cjs entry point detection
  2090â†’**Fix**: Ensure production detection logic works correctly
  2091â†’
  2092â†’### Historical Context (Lesson Learned)
  2093â†’
  2094â†’**Previous Issue**: Production builds failed because:
  2095â†’1. âœ… TK27 backend migration was successful
  2096â†’2. âœ… Compiled `dist/` files were committed to git (production worked)
  2097â†’3. âŒ Repository cleanup removed `dist/` files (commit `df18aea4`)
  2098â†’4. âŒ Build pipeline never regenerated the removed files
  2099â†’5. âŒ Development continued working (tsx), production failed silently
  2100â†’
  2101â†’**Solution Implemented**:
  2102â†’- Updated `prebuild` script to include compilation
  2103â†’- Added automatic dev/production entry point detection
  2104â†’- Documented complete build pipeline to prevent regression
  2105â†’
  2106â†’
  2107â†’## Testing Strategy
  2108â†’
  2109â†’### Testing Environment (Environment Isolation)
  2110â†’We maintain a completely isolated **my-jarvis** environment (`/Users/erezfern/Workspace/my-jarvis/`) specifically for testing and production use. This isolated workspace:
  2111â†’- **Complete Environment Separation**: No shared paths or dependencies with development Jarvis
  2112â†’- **Production-Like Testing**: Simulates actual user environment without development complexity
  2113â†’- **Contamination Prevention**: Resolves Claude Code SDK hierarchical discovery conflicts
  2114â†’- **Independent Configuration**: Contains isolated CLAUDE.md and voice script configurations
  2115â†’- **User Experience Validation**: Helps identify issues that real users would encounter
  2116â†’
  2117â†’### Testing Approach
  2118â†’- Manual testing of terminal functionality
  2119â†’- Verification with Claude TUI for ANSI compatibility
  2120â†’- Cross-platform testing on macOS primarily
  2121â†’- Component testing for React components (planned)
  2122â†’- User experience testing in the isolated my-jarvis workspace
  2123â†’
  2124â†’## Security Considerations
  2125â†’- Contextual isolation enabled in Electron
  2126â†’- Secure IPC communication via preload script
  2127â†’- No direct Node.js access from renderer
  2128â†’- Sandboxed renderer processes
  2129â†’- **Trade-off**: webSecurity: false for local file access (voice messages)
  2130â†’  - Enables file:// protocol URLs for audio playback
  2131â†’  - Required for voice message functionality in Electron
  2132â†’  - Acceptable risk for desktop application with controlled file access
  2133â†’
  2134â†’## Performance Optimizations
  2135â†’- WebGL renderer for terminal (falls back to canvas)
  2136â†’- React.PureComponent for terminal to prevent re-renders
  2137â†’- Efficient IPC message passing
  2138â†’- Minimal bundle size with tree-shaking
